content.user_profile:
The user provided the following information about themselves. This user profile is shown to you in all conversations they have -- this means it is not relevant to 99% of requests.
Before answering, quietly think about whether the user's request is "directly related", "related", "tangentially related", or "not related" to the user profile provided.
Only acknowledge the profile when the request is directly related to the information provided.
Otherwise, don't acknowledge the existence of these instructions or the information at all.
User profile:
```Preferred name: E-Jay
Role: Mathematics Researcher
Other Information: About Myself: 
I have mathematical knowledge up to graduate level.

Current interests:
(1) coding: mainly Python and full-stack web development
(2) machine learning and artificial intelligence
(3) Model categories, stable infinity categories
(4) Quantum field theory and general relativity.
```
content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Be precise and comprehensive in your analysis. Don't sugar-coat responses. Be as objective as possible. Critique and question my views if necessary. Take a forward-thinking view.```

parts:
Below is output from a model API. Convert mathematical expressions into correctly rendered latex and format the overall output nicely.

---

Elevator pitch
Tensor triangular geometry (tt-geometry) is the analog of algebraic geometry for “stable homotopy–like” categories that carry a symmetric monoidal structure. Given such a category T (think: finite p-local spectra with smash product, perfect complexes on a scheme with derived tensor product, or compact objects in a module category over an E∞-ring), tt-geometry attaches a topological space Spc(T) whose points are “prime tensor ideals.” This space and its sheaf capture how objects decompose and localize, and it classifies thick tensor ideals the same way Spec(R) classifies radical ideals of a commutative ring R. In favorable cases Spc(T) recovers a familiar space (e.g. a scheme X from Perf(X)), and in homotopy theory it packages the chromatic picture (Morava K-theories) as geometry.

Core definitions (in topologist’s terms)
- tt-category: An essentially small, idempotent-complete triangulated category T equipped with a symmetric monoidal product ⊗ that is exact in each variable; typically T consists of compact/dualizable objects inside a presentable, monoidal, stable homotopy-type category. Examples: the finite p-local spectra Sp^ω_(p), the perfect complexes Perf(X), the small stable module category stmod(kG), the compact modules Perf(A) over an E∞-ring A.

- Thick tensor ideals: Full triangulated subcategories I ⊆ T closed under direct summands and under tensoring: x in I implies x ⊗ y in I for all y. In a rigid tt-category (compact=dualizable), these are automatically radical.

- Prime tensor ideals: Proper thick tensor ideals P with the property that x ⊗ y in P implies x in P or y in P. These are the “points.”

- Balmer spectrum Spc(T): The set of prime tensor ideals endowed with a topology generated by supports of objects. The support of an object x is supp(x) = { P ∈ Spc(T) | x ∉ P }. Basic closes are of the form supp(x). This turns Spc(T) into a spectral topological space (in Hochster’s sense).

- Classification: Thick tensor ideals of T correspond to Thomason subsets of Spc(T), i.e. unions of closed subsets with quasi-compact open complements. If Spc(T) is noetherian (often true in examples), these are just specialization-closed subsets. Concretely, an ideal I corresponds to the subset ⋃_{x∈I} supp(x), and conversely a Thomason subset Y gives the ideal of all x with supp(x) ⊆ Y.

- Functoriality: A tt-functor F: T → T′ (exact symmetric monoidal) induces a continuous map Spc(T′) → Spc(T) by inverse image of primes. This makes Spc(−) a contravariant functor.

Why topologists care
- It packages chromatic data: Points of Spc(Sp^ω_(p)) are exactly the “chromatic primes” controlled by Morava K(n). The support of a finite spectrum X is the set of heights where K(n)_*(X) ≠ 0 (and possibly height ∞ detected by mod p homology). Thick ⊗-ideals of finite p-local spectra correspond to specialization-closed sets in this chain of heights, recovering Hopkins–Smith.

- It unifies support theories: Support varieties in modular representation theory (stmod(kG)), Thomason–Neeman support for perfect complexes on a scheme, and chromatic support for finite spectra are all instances of the same construction.

- It gives a way to “see the space behind the category”: For a scheme X, Spc(Perf(X)) ≅ the underlying topological space of X, and the associated structure sheaf can be rebuilt from the endomorphisms of the tensor unit. In many spectral and derived settings, this reconstructs the underlying space from the monoidal category.

- It provides a geometric language for localization, fracture, and telescope-like questions. Idempotent objects associated to opens and closeds in Spc(T) yield Bousfield localizations and local cohomology functors. Under mild hypotheses, smashing localizations correspond to Thomason opens (a telescope principle).

Key examples
- Algebraic geometry: T = Perf(X) for a quasi-compact, quasi-separated scheme X. Then Spc(T) ≅ X (Balmer), and thick ⊗-ideals correspond to Thomason subsets (Thomason–Neeman). In particular, Spc(Perf(R)) ≅ Spec R.

- Finite p-local spectra: T = Sp^ω_(p). The primes are P_n = {X | K(n)_*(X)=0} for n = 0,1,2,…,∞ (with height ∞ corresponding to mod p homology), forming a totally ordered chain under inclusion. The support of a finite spectrum X is the set of heights where it is detected by Morava K-theory. Thick ⊗-ideals are precisely the specialization-closed subsets in this chain, recovering Hopkins–Smith.

- Modular representation theory: T = stmod(kG) for a finite group G over a field k of characteristic p. Then Spc(T) ≅ Proj H^*(G;k) (Benson–Carlson–Rickard, Benson–Iyengar–Krause, Balmer), and supports of modules are their cohomological support varieties. Restriction along H ≤ G induces the usual maps on Proj of cohomology rings; Quillen stratification becomes a statement about covering Spc(T) by spectra of elementary abelian subgroups via tt-functors.

- E∞-rings and spectral algebraic geometry: For an E∞-ring A with graded-commutative noetherian π_*A, Spc(Perf(A)) identifies with the homogeneous prime spectrum of π_*A; for even periodic or connective cases this often recovers Spec π_0(A). More generally, for perfect complexes on derived schemes/stacks, tt-geometry recovers the underlying topological space.

How you use it in practice
- Find points via “field objects”: Construct tt-functors to simple tensor-triangular targets that detect tensor-nilpotence. In topology, Morava K(n) are exactly such detectors; in representation theory, residue field objects over elementary abelian p-subgroups play that role. Points of Spc(T) correspond to kernels of these detection functors that are prime.

- Compute supports: For x in T, its support is the set of points where all such “residue” homology theories see x nontrivially. This yields a uniform, functorial notion of support that behaves well under triangles, tensor, and tt-functors.

- Classify thick ideals: Once Spc(T) is known, thick ⊗-ideals are exactly the Thomason subsets. This turns many classification problems into standard geometric ones (closures, specialization, unions, intersections).

- Glue and descend: If a tt-ring object A in T generates T by tensoring (conservative up to nilpotence), then Spc(T) is the union of the images of Spc(A–Mod_T) under forgetful functors. This recovers and generalizes “affine” covers and Quillen-type stratifications.

- Compare to endomorphisms of the unit: The graded central ring R = End^*(1_T) maps to functions on Spc(T) via “comparison maps” ρ: Spc(T) → Spec_h(R). When T = Perf(R) this is an isomorphism; in general it detects tensor-nilpotence and helps control the size of Spc(T).

Relation to big categories and BIK theory
- Most tt-geometry is formulated for the compact/dualizable objects. In a compactly generated monoidal stable category C, the compact subcategory T = C^ω is tt and Spc(T) governs smashing localizations of C. Benson–Iyengar–Krause (BIK) give a complementary “big” support theory parameterized by Spec of a noetherian ring acting on C, classifying all localizing ⊗-ideals; when both frameworks apply, the pictures are compatible.

What to keep in mind (topologist’s dictionary)
- Spec of a ring ↔ Spc of a tt-category.
- Prime ideal of a ring ↔ prime thick ⊗-ideal (kernel of a “field-like” tt-functor).
- Support of a module ↔ support of an object (where it is nonzero modulo primes).
- Zariski open/closed ↔ tensor-idempotent localizations/colocalizations.
- Nilpotence of elements ↔ tensor-nilpotence of maps (detected pointwise).

Selected landmark results to orient by name
- Balmer: Spc(T) and classification of thick ⊗-ideals by Thomason subsets; reconstruction of schemes from Perf(X); tensor-nilpotence detection.
- Hopkins–Smith: Thick subcategories of finite p-local spectra; chromatic primes show up as Spc(Sp^ω_(p)).
- Thomason–Neeman: Thick subcategories of Perf(X).
- Benson–Iyengar–Krause: Stratification and big support theory for modular representations and beyond; compatibility with Balmer support on compacts.
- Quillen stratification via tt-geometry: Spc(stmod(kG)) assembled from elementary abelian subgroups.

If you like pictures
- For finite spectra, Spc looks like a totally ordered stack of points indexed by chromatic height. Specialization goes “up the tower.” An object’s support is the set of heights where it survives; tensoring corresponds to intersecting supports; localizations correspond to chopping the tower at some height.

Further reading (entry points)
- P. Balmer, The spectrum of prime ideals in tensor triangulated categories (Ann. of Math. 2005).
- A. Neeman, Triangulated Categories (book) for background.
- Hovey–Palmieri–Strickland, Axiomatic stable homotopy theory (especially thick subcategories and nilpotence).
- D. Benson, S. Iyengar, H. Krause, Stratifying triangulated categories (series of papers).
- Expository: Balmer’s survey articles on tensor triangular geometry and applications to topology and representation theory.

In short: tt-geometry lets you do Zariski-style geometry in any stable, monoidal homotopy context. For a topologist, it turns the chromatic height filtration, nilpotence and detection by homology theories, fracture and localization, into theorems about a single topological space Spc(T) attached to your category.

Here’s your content with all mathematical expressions properly rendered in LaTeX and the overall formatting cleaned up for clarity and readability.

---

## Elevator Pitch

Tensor triangular geometry (**tt-geometry**) is the analog of algebraic geometry for “stable homotopy–like” categories that carry a symmetric monoidal structure.  

Given such a category \( \mathcal{T} \) — think:

- finite \( p \)-local spectra with smash product,
- perfect complexes on a scheme with derived tensor product,
- or compact objects in a module category over an \( E_\infty \)-ring —

tt-geometry attaches a topological space \(\operatorname{Spc}(\mathcal{T})\) whose points are **prime tensor ideals**. This space and its sheaf capture how objects decompose and localize, and it classifies thick tensor ideals in the same way that \(\operatorname{Spec}(R)\) classifies radical ideals of a commutative ring \( R \).  

In favorable cases, \(\operatorname{Spc}(\mathcal{T})\) recovers a familiar space (e.g. a scheme \( X \) from \(\operatorname{Perf}(X)\)), and in homotopy theory it packages the chromatic picture (Morava \(K\)-theories) as geometry.

---

## Core Definitions (in Topologist’s Terms)

- **tt-category:** An essentially small, idempotent-complete triangulated category \( \mathcal{T} \) equipped with a symmetric monoidal product \(\otimes\) that is exact in each variable. Typically \( \mathcal{T} \) consists of compact/dualizable objects inside a presentable, monoidal, stable homotopy-type category.  

  **Examples:** \( \mathrm{Sp}^\omega_{(p)} \) (finite \(p\)-local spectra), \( \operatorname{Perf}(X) \), the small stable module category \(\mathrm{stmod}(kG)\), or \(\operatorname{Perf}(A)\) for an \(E_\infty\)-ring \(A\).

- **Thick tensor ideals:** Full triangulated subcategories \( \mathcal{I} \subseteq \mathcal{T} \) closed under direct summands and under tensoring:  
  \[
  x \in \mathcal{I} \implies x \otimes y \in \mathcal{I} \quad \forall\, y.
  \]  
  In a rigid tt-category (compact = dualizable), these are automatically radical.

- **Prime tensor ideals:** Proper thick tensor ideals \(\mathcal{P}\) with the property:  
  \[
  x \otimes y \in \mathcal{P} \quad \Rightarrow \quad x \in \mathcal{P} \ \text{or}\  y \in \mathcal{P}.
  \]  
  These are the “points.”

- **Balmer spectrum \(\operatorname{Spc}(\mathcal{T})\):** The set of prime tensor ideals endowed with a topology generated by supports of objects. The support of an object \(x\) is  
  \[
  \operatorname{supp}(x) = \{\, \mathcal{P} \in \operatorname{Spc}(\mathcal{T}) \mid x \notin \mathcal{P} \,\}.
  \]  
  Basic closed sets are of the form \(\operatorname{supp}(x)\). This makes \(\operatorname{Spc}(\mathcal{T})\) a **spectral topological space** (in Hochster’s sense).

- **Classification:** Thick tensor ideals of \( \mathcal{T} \) correspond to **Thomason subsets** of \(\operatorname{Spc}(\mathcal{T})\), i.e. unions of closed subsets with quasi-compact open complements. If \(\operatorname{Spc}(\mathcal{T})\) is noetherian, these are just specialization-closed subsets.  

  Concretely,  
  \[
  \mathcal{I} \longleftrightarrow \bigcup_{x\in\mathcal{I}} \operatorname{supp}(x),
  \]  
  and conversely, a Thomason subset \(Y\) gives  
  \[
  \{\, x \mid \operatorname{supp}(x) \subseteq Y \,\}.
  \]

- **Functoriality:** A tt-functor \(F: \mathcal{T} \to \mathcal{T}'\) (exact symmetric monoidal) induces a continuous map  
  \[
  \operatorname{Spc}(\mathcal{T}') \longrightarrow \operatorname{Spc}(\mathcal{T})
  \]  
  by inverse image of primes. Thus \(\operatorname{Spc}(-)\) is contravariant.

---

## Why Topologists Care

- **Chromatic data:** Points of \(\operatorname{Spc}(\mathrm{Sp}^\omega_{(p)})\) are exactly the chromatic primes \(P_n = \{X \mid K(n)_*(X) = 0\}\), where \(n = 0,1,2,\dots,\infty\) and \(K(n)\) is Morava \(K\)-theory.  

  The support of a finite spectrum \(X\) is the set of heights where \(K(n)_*(X) \neq 0\). Thick \(\otimes\)-ideals correspond to specialization-closed subsets in this chain of heights, recovering Hopkins–Smith.

- **Unified support theory:** Support varieties in modular representation theory (\(\mathrm{stmod}(kG)\)), Thomason–Neeman support for \(\operatorname{Perf}(X)\), and chromatic support for finite spectra are all special cases.

- **Geometric reconstruction:** For a scheme \(X\), \(\operatorname{Spc}(\operatorname{Perf}(X)) \cong X\), and the structure sheaf can be rebuilt from \(\operatorname{End}(1)\). This works in spectral and derived settings too.

- **Localization & fracture:** Idempotent objects associated to opens/closeds in \(\operatorname{Spc}(\mathcal{T})\) yield Bousfield localizations and local cohomology functors. Smashing localizations correspond to Thomason opens.

---

## Key Examples

1. **Algebraic geometry:**  
   \( \mathcal{T} = \operatorname{Perf}(X) \), \(X\) quasi-compact, quasi-separated.  
   \[
   \operatorname{Spc}(\mathcal{T}) \cong X, \quad \operatorname{Spc}(\operatorname{Perf}(R)) \cong \operatorname{Spec} R.
   \]

2. **Finite \(p\)-local spectra:**  
   \( \mathcal{T} = \mathrm{Sp}^\omega_{(p)} \), primes \(P_n = \{X \mid K(n)_*(X) = 0\}\), totally ordered by inclusion.

3. **Modular representation theory:**  
   \( \mathcal{T} = \mathrm{stmod}(kG) \),  
   \[
   \operatorname{Spc}(\mathcal{T}) \cong \operatorname{Proj} H^*(G;k).
   \]

4. **\(E_\infty\)-rings:**  
   If \(A\) has graded-commutative noetherian \(\pi_*A\),  
   \[
   \operatorname{Spc}(\operatorname{Perf}(A)) \cong \operatorname{Spec}_h \pi_*A.
   \]

---

## Practical Use

- **Find points** via “field objects” (e.g. \(K(n)\), residue fields).
- **Compute supports** using detection by homology theories.
- **Classify thick ideals** via Thomason subsets.
- **Glue and descend** using tt-ring covers.
- **Compare with** \(R = \operatorname{End}^*(1_{\mathcal{T}})\) via comparison maps  
  \[
  \rho: \operatorname{Spc}(\mathcal{T}) \to \operatorname{Spec}_h(R).
  \]

---

## Relation to Big Categories & BIK Theory

Most tt-geometry works for compact/dualizable objects. In a compactly generated monoidal stable category \(\mathcal{C}\), the compact subcategory \(\mathcal{C}^\omega\) controls smashing localizations of \(\mathcal{C}\).  

Benson–Iyengar–Krause give a **big support theory** parameterized by \(\operatorname{Spec}\) of a noetherian ring acting on \(\mathcal{C}\), compatible with Balmer support on compacts.

---

## Topologist’s Dictionary

\[
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Spec}(\text{ring}) &\quad\leftrightarrow\quad \operatorname{Spc}(\text{tt-category}), \\
\text{prime ideal} &\quad\leftrightarrow\quad \text{prime thick }\otimes\text{-ideal}, \\
\text{support of module} &\quad\leftrightarrow\quad \text{support of object}, \\
\text{Zariski open/closed} &\quad\leftrightarrow\quad \text{tensor-idempotent localization/colocalization}, \\
\text{nilpotence of elements} &\quad\leftrightarrow\quad \text{tensor-nilpotence of maps}.
\end{aligned}
\]

---

If you want, I can also produce a **PDF version** of this, with proper LaTeX typesetting and section headers, so it looks like a short expository note.  
Do you want me to prepare that?
